awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exploration of Near-Field Thermophotovoltaic Energy Conversion for Efficient Thermal Energy Recycling
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET-1236239/1236052
PIs: Park/Cho 

A thermophotovoltaic (TPV) system is a promising energy conversion device that generates the electric power from the infrared thermal radiation. However, its low power throughput and poor conversion efficiency restricts the usage in practical applications. One solution for resolving these issues is to utilize near-field thermal radiation, which can exceed the blackbody thermal radiation by several orders of magnitude. However, due to difficulties in maintaining the parallel nanoscale gap between the emitter and the receiver, experimental investigations of near-field thermal radiation have been limited to simple spherical or point-like emitter geometries. This proposal thus aims to experimentally investigate near-field thermal radiation between planar structures within a submicron vacuum gap and its contribution to the near-field TPV energy conversion. The innovative aspects of the proposed research are (1) to microfabricate a suspended thermal emitter (heater) to achieve a uniform temperature and minimize conduction heat loss; (2) to vacuum-package the microheater with a diaphragm to allow thermal radiation as the only heat transfer mechanism between the heater and the diaphragm; and (3) to precisely control the vacuum gap between the heater and the diaphragm by changing the diaphragm curvature with the external pressure. 

This project will provide the quantitative measurement of the near-field radiative heat transfer between two parallel plates at vacuum gap distances of a few hundred nanometers. In addition, the advantage of near-field TPV energy conversion device will be systematically examined, which also will provide the measurements of the power throughput and conversion efficiency of the near-field TPV device. The theoretical aspect of this research will improve our fundamental understanding of near-field interactions between thermally emitted electromagnetic waves and nanostructures via surface plasmon resonance, scattering, diffraction, and photon localization. 

The success of the proposed research will enhance scientific and technological understanding of the nanoscale TPV energy conversion while promoting teaching, training, and learning. The PIs will put forth considerable efforts to involve graduate and undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented group, in cutting-edge nanotechnology research. They will gain hands-on experiences in micro/nanofabrication, thermal and electrical characterization of micro/nanodevices, and near-field radiative heat transfer measurements. The outcome of the proposed research will be incorporated into courses, such as Micro/Nanoscale Energy Transport at URI, and disseminated to the public through Thermal-Fluids Central (http://www.thermalfluidscentral.org) and technical journals.

por.por_cntn:
Near-field thermal radiation has attracted lots of researchers to study the fundamentals and its application in different fields. A great potential of near-field thermal radiation can be exploit in energy conversion schemes to improve the power throughput and conversion efficiency of thermophotovoltaic systems. The performance of the near-field TPV system has been analyzed by several research groups where most of these works have treated the TPV cell as a one-piece component and assumed the quantum efficiency of the cell to be 100%. Although the performance of the near-field TPV system has been widely studied, there is still lack of fundamental understanding about local energy conversion processes and loss mechanisms within the TPV cell. Moreover, most of the near-field TPV studies to date have focused on the energy perspective, leaving fundamental questions on the theoretically maximum power generation of the near-field TPV system and a thermodynamic limit of its energy conversion efficiency based on the second law of thermodynamics. Moreover, experimental study of the near-field thermal radiation has been very challenging due to the difficulty of maintaining a nanoscale vacuum gap between two flat plates that can be potentially used for energy conversion purposes. Then the objectives of these projects can be named to be: (1) Fundamental studies of energy and entropy balances in the near-field TPV system to understand its theoretical maximum power generation and a thermodynamic limit of the energy conversion efficiency based on the second law of thermodynamics. (2) To experimentally study the near-field thermal radiation using a nanopositioning system, and (3) Feasibility study of near-field enhanced thermionic energy conversion as a novel way of energy harvesting using near-field thermal radiation.

The outcomes of these projects have provided the following intellectual merits: (1) calculation of the local entropy generation and exergy flux within a TPV cell was done for the first time resulting in a better understanding of the contribution of different loss mechanisms throughout the cell. Furthermore, the maximum theoretical conversion efficiency was calculated using the exergy analysis for a NTPV system, indicating a great potential room for improvement of the TPV cell designs. (2) We have developed an all-inclusive experimental setup to measure near-field thermal radiation between two flat plates. This experimental setup is proved to be used successfully to measure the near-field thermal radiation transferred between two relatively large (5x5 mm2) quartz samples, while maintain a remarkable temperature difference between them (ΔT≈160K). The feedback control of the gap distance throughout the experiment along with the capability of closed-loop controlling the both sides temperatures enable accurate measurements. In addition, very simple design of the samples gives us the opportunity to try various metamaterials (such as hyperbolic metamaterials) for the measurement of near-field thermal radiation. (3) We have integrated near-field thermal radiation with thermionic energy conversion to claim a novel way of energy harvesting called near-field enhanced thermionic energy conversion. By making use of photoexcitation and thermal excitation of electrons in a low-bandgap semiconductor cathode, our calculation reveals that the thermionic current density can be greatly enhanced, and the energy conversion efficiency is much higher than other competing technologies.

These projects have also created significant broader impacts on knowledge and society, education, and outreach. The obtained experimental and numerical results of near-field thermal radiation between two plates, fundamental studies of energy and entropy in a TPV cell and near-field enhanced thermionic conversion will provide a strong tool to fill in a knowledge gap and provide timely support for the further advancement of near-field TPV designs and energy conversion applications. This project has provided training opportunities for a couple of PhD students and undergraduate students. The knowledge achieved from this research has been disseminated through multiple journal publications and presentations in conferences, and more manuscripts are under review and in reparation as a result of the very well experimental setup and the broader knowledge about fundamentals of energy conversion processes in a TPV cell. To advance the nanotechnology education, we have developed a LEGO-AFM package as an educational tool and a low-budget AFM by working with a senior design project team. The LEGO-AFM project has been disseminated through the PI’s group website (http://kpark.mech.utah.edu) for details of assembly and operations and has been adopted in outreach and educational activities, such as Engineering Day at the University of Utah. Overall, research and education activities involved in this project will enhance scientific and technological understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning.
